required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Buzzy System Compared to Topical Anaesthesia During Maxillary Buccal Infiltration Injection in Children.
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Buzzy System (Vibrating Device) Compared to Topical Anaesthesia on Pain Reduction During Injection of Conventional Maxillary Buccal Infiltration Anaesthesia in Children: A Randomized Clinical Trial Study

brief_summary.textblock: Aim of the study is to test the efficacy of a commercially available vibrating device (Buzzy System) over conventional topical anaesthesia in reducing pain among children receiving maxillary buccal infiltration anaesthesia.

study_design_info.masking_description: Both the patient and the investigator cannot be blinded due to the different techniques.

primary_outcome.measure: Pain Perception during local anaesthesia injection
primary_outcome.time_frame: Procedure (immediately after the administration of local anesthesia)
primary_outcome.description: Pain intensity directly after the injection recorded by Wong-Baker faces pain rating scale and Faces, Legs, Arms, Crying, Consolability (FLACC) scale.

arm_group.description: Maxillary anesthetic infiltration injection with (Mepecaine - L 1.8ml Carpule) after activating the buzzy device over the area/cheek where the local anaesthetic solution is to be delivered.
Maxillary anesthetic infiltration injection with (Mepecaine - L 1.8ml Carpule) after topical application with 20% Benzocaine topical gel only.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Children classified as cooperative or potentially cooperative according to Wright's classification of child behaviour with rating 3 (positive) or 4 (definitely positive) according to Frankl behaviour rating scale.
2. Children aged 5-7 years old.
3. Children requiring maxillary buccal infiltration anaesthesia injection for dental treatment.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Children with any neurological or psychological disorders.
2. Children with known allergy to topical or local anaesthetic agents.
3. Parental refusal for participation.
